    73→## Files to Reference
    74→
    75→These files should be examined to understand existing patterns:
    76→
    77→| File | Pattern to Copy |
    78→|------|----------------|
    79→| `frontend/src/App.tsx` | Entry point structure and routing patterns |
    80→| Existing components in `frontend/src/components/` | Component structure, TypeScript typing, Emotion styling patterns |

    82→
    83→**Note:** Since the discovery phase did not identify specific reference files, the implementation should follow Material-UI and Emotion best practices as indicated by the project dependencies.
    84→
    85→## Patterns to Follow
    86→
    87→### Emotion Styled Components Pattern
    88→
    89→Based on the project's use of Emotion, components should follow this pattern:
    90→
    91→```typescript
    92→import styled from '@emotion/styled';
    93→
    94→// Define styled components
    95→export const HeroContainer = styled.div`
    96→  background-color: #1a1a1a; /* Dark theme */
    97→  padding: 80px 20px;
    98→  min-height: 600px;
    99→  display: flex;
   100→  flex-direction: column;
   101→  align-items: center;
   102→  justify-content: center;
   103→`;
   104→
   105→export const HeroTitle = styled.h1`
   106→  color: #ffffff;
   107→  font-size: 3rem;
   108→  font-weight: bold;
   109→  text-align: center;
   110→  margin-bottom: 1.5rem;
   111→
   112→  @media (max-width: 768px) {
   113→    font-size: 2rem;
   114→  }
   115→`;
   116→```
   117→
   118→**Key Points:**
   119→- Use Emotion's styled API for component styling
   120→- Implement responsive design with media queries
   121→- Follow dark theme color scheme
   122→- Maintain type safety with TypeScript
   123→
   124→### React Component Structure Pattern
   125→
   126→```typescript
   127→import React from 'react';
   128→import { HeroContainer, HeroTitle, CTAButton } from './Hero.styles';
   129→
   130→interface HeroProps {
   131→  title: string;
   132→  subtitle: string;
   133→  ctaPrimary: string;
   134→  ctaSecondary?: string;
   135→}
   136→
   137→export const Hero: React.FC<HeroProps> = ({
   138→  title,
   139→  subtitle,
   140→  ctaPrimary,
   141→  ctaSecondary
   142→}) => {
   143→  return (
   144→    <HeroContainer>
   145→      <HeroTitle>{title}</HeroTitle>
   146→      {/* Component implementation */}
   147→    </HeroContainer>
   148→  );
   149→};
   150→```
   151→
   152→**Key Points:**
   153→- Define TypeScript interfaces for props
   154→- Use functional components with React.FC
   155→- Separate styled components from logic
   156→
   157→### Material-UI Integration Pattern
   158→
   159→Since the project uses Material-UI, consider using MUI components where appropriate:
   160→
   161→```typescript
   162→import { Button, Container, Typography } from '@mui/material';
   163→import { styled } from '@emotion/styled';
   164→
   165→// Can extend MUI components with Emotion
   166→const StyledButton = styled(Button)`
   167→  background: linear-gradient(45deg, #2196F3 30%, #21CBF3 90%);
   168→  color: white;
   169→  padding: 12px 30px;
   170→  border-radius: 8px;
   171→`;
   172→```
   173→
   174→**Key Points:**
   175→- Leverage existing MUI components for accessibility and consistency
   176→- Extend MUI components with Emotion for custom styling
   177→- Use MUI's theming system if available
   178→
   179→## Requirements
   180→
   181→### Functional Requirements
   182→
   183→1. **Dark Theme Hero Container**
   184→   - Description: A full-width hero section with dark background that contrasts with light text and CTAs
   185→   - Acceptance:
   186→     - Background color is dark (e.g., #1a1a1a or similar dark shade)
   187→     - Text is highly readable (WCAG AA contrast ratio of at least 4.5:1)
   188→     - Section spans full viewport width
   189→     - Minimum height ensures content is above the fold on desktop
   190→
   191→2. **Primary and Secondary CTA Buttons**
   192→   - Description: Two distinct call-to-action buttons with different visual hierarchy
   193→   - Acceptance:
   194→     - Primary CTA is visually prominent (filled, bright color)
   195→     - Secondary CTA is less prominent (outlined or secondary color)
   196→     - Both buttons have hover states
   197→     - Buttons are keyboard accessible (focus states visible)
   198→     - Click events can be attached (onClick handlers available)
   199→
   200→3. **Trust Logos Section**
   201→   - Description: Display of partner/client logos to establish credibility
   202→   - Acceptance:
   203→     - Logos are displayed in a horizontal row (or grid on mobile)
   204→     - Logos are appropriately sized and maintain aspect ratio
   205→     - Section is clearly separated from hero content (visual divider or spacing)
   206→     - Alt text is provided for accessibility
   207→
   208→4. **Responsive Design**
   209→   - Description: Hero section adapts to different screen sizes
   210→   - Acceptance:
   211→     - Desktop (≥1024px): Full layout with large typography
   212→     - Tablet (768px-1023px): Adjusted spacing and font sizes
   213→     - Mobile (≤767px): Stacked layout, smaller typography, adjusted CTA button sizing
   214→     - No horizontal scrolling on any breakpoint
   215→     - Touch targets are at least 44x44px on mobile
   216→
   217→5. **Accessibility Compliance**
   218→   - Description: Hero section meets WCAG 2.1 Level AA standards
   219→   - Acceptance:
   220→     - All interactive elements are keyboard navigable
   221→     - Focus indicators are visible
   222→     - ARIA labels are provided where needed
   223→     - Color contrast ratios meet standards
   224→     - Semantic HTML elements are used
   225→
   226→### Edge Cases
   227→
   228→1. **Long Hero Text** - If title or subtitle is longer than expected, implement text overflow handling (ellipsis or wrap) to prevent layout breaking
   229→
   230→2. **Missing Logo Assets** - Display placeholder or gracefully hide logo section if assets are not available
   231→
   232→3. **Small Viewport Heights** - On very short screens (e.g., landscape mobile), ensure hero doesn't take up more than viewport height to allow scrolling to content below
   233→
   234→4. **High Contrast Mode** - Ensure component remains usable in browser high contrast mode for accessibility
   235→
   236→5. **Logo Count Variations** - Trust logos section should handle 3-6 logos gracefully, adjusting spacing as needed
   237→
   238→## Implementation Notes
   239→
   240→### DO
   241→- Follow the design specifications in `01-hero-dark.png` exactly for colors, spacing, and layout
   242→- Use Emotion styled components consistently throughout the implementation

1→import { Routes, Route, Navigate, Outlet } from 'react-router-dom'
     2→import Layout from './components/layout/Layout'
     3→import LandingPage from './pages/LandingPage'
     4→import LoginPage from './pages/LoginPage'
     5→import DashboardPage from './pages/DashboardPage'
     6→import ProjectsPage from './pages/ProjectsPage'
     7→import ProjectDetailPage from './pages/ProjectDetailPage'
     8→import EquipmentPage from './pages/EquipmentPage'
     9→import MaterialsPage from './pages/MaterialsPage'
    10→import MeetingsPage from './pages/MeetingsPage'
    11→import ApprovalsPage from './pages/ApprovalsPage'
    12→import AreasPage from './pages/AreasPage'
    13→import ContactsPage from './pages/ContactsPage'
    14→import AuditLogPage from './pages/AuditLogPage'
    15→import InspectionsPage from './pages/InspectionsPage'
    16→import RFIPage from './pages/RFIPage'
    17→
    18→function ProtectedRoute() {
    19→  const token = localStorage.getItem('authToken')
    20→  if (!token) {
    21→    return <Navigate to="/login" replace />
    22→  }
    23→  return <Outlet />
    24→}
    25→
    26→export default function App() {
    27→  return (
    28→    <Routes>
    29→        <Route path="/" element={<LandingPage />} />
    30→        <Route path="/login" element={<LoginPage />} />
    31→
    32→        <Route element={<ProtectedRoute />}>
    33→          <Route element={<Layout />}>
    34→            <Route path="/dashboard" element={<DashboardPage />} />
    35→            <Route path="/projects" element={<ProjectsPage />} />
    36→
    37→            <Route path="/projects/:projectId" element={<ProjectDetailPage />}>
    38→              <Route path="equipment" element={<EquipmentPage />} />
    39→              <Route path="materials" element={<MaterialsPage />} />
    40→              <Route path="meetings" element={<MeetingsPage />} />
    41→              <Route path="approvals" element={<ApprovalsPage />} />
    42→              <Route path="areas" element={<AreasPage />} />
    43→              <Route path="contacts" element={<ContactsPage />} />
    44→              <Route path="inspections" element={<InspectionsPage />} />
    45→              <Route path="rfis" element={<RFIPage />} />
    46→            </Route>
    47→
    48→            <Route path="/approvals" element={<ApprovalsPage />} />
    49→            <Route path="/audit" element={<AuditLogPage />} />
    50→          </Route>
    51→        </Route>
    52→
    53→        <Route path="*" element={<Navigate to="/" replace />} />
    54→      </Routes>
    55→  )
    56→}
    57→

1→import { Button as MuiButton, ButtonProps as MuiButtonProps, CircularProgress } from '@mui/material'
     2→import { styled } from '@mui/material/styles'
     3→
     4→export interface ButtonProps extends Omit<MuiButtonProps, 'variant'> {
     5→  variant?: 'primary' | 'secondary' | 'tertiary' | 'danger' | 'success'
     6→  loading?: boolean
     7→  icon?: React.ReactNode
     8→  iconPosition?: 'start' | 'end'
     9→}
    10→
    11→const StyledButton = styled(MuiButton)(() => ({
    12→  fontWeight: 600,
    13→  transition: 'all 200ms ease-out',
    14→  '&:hover': {
    15→    transform: 'translateY(-1px)',
    16→  },
    17→  '&:active': {
    18→    transform: 'scale(0.98)',
    19→  },
    20→  '&.Mui-disabled': {
    21→    transform: 'none',
    22→  },
    23→}))
    24→
    25→export function Button({
    26→  variant = 'primary',
    27→  loading = false,
    28→  icon,
    29→  iconPosition = 'start',
    30→  children,
    31→  disabled,
    32→  ...props
    33→}: ButtonProps) {
    34→  const getMuiVariant = (): MuiButtonProps['variant'] => {
    35→    switch (variant) {
    36→      case 'primary':
    37→      case 'danger':
    38→      case 'success':
    39→        return 'contained'
    40→      case 'secondary':
    41→        return 'outlined'
    42→      case 'tertiary':
    43→        return 'text'
    44→      default:
    45→        return 'contained'
    46→    }
    47→  }
    48→
    49→  const getColor = (): MuiButtonProps['color'] => {
    50→    switch (variant) {
    51→      case 'primary':
    52→        return 'primary'
    53→      case 'secondary':
    54→        return 'primary'
    55→      case 'tertiary':
    56→        return 'primary'
    57→      case 'danger':
    58→        return 'error'
    59→      case 'success':
    60→        return 'success'
    61→      default:
    62→        return 'primary'
    63→    }
    64→  }
    65→
    66→  const startIcon = icon && iconPosition === 'start' ? icon : undefined
    67→  const endIcon = icon && iconPosition === 'end' ? icon : undefined
    68→
    69→  return (
    70→    <StyledButton
    71→      variant={getMuiVariant()}
    72→      color={getColor()}
    73→      disabled={disabled || loading}
    74→      startIcon={loading ? <CircularProgress size={18} color="inherit" /> : startIcon}
    75→      endIcon={endIcon}
    76→      {...props}
    77→    >
    78→      {children}
    79→    </StyledButton>
    80→  )
    81→}
    82→
    83→export function IconButton({
    84→  children,
    85→  loading = false,
    86→  variant: _,
    87→  ...props
    88→}: Omit<ButtonProps, 'icon' | 'iconPosition'>) {
    89→  return (
    90→    <StyledButton
    91→      variant="contained"
    92→      color="primary"
    93→      disabled={props.disabled || loading}
    94→      sx={{
    95→        minWidth: 'auto',
    96→        p: 1,
    97→        ...props.sx,
    98→      }}
    99→      {...props}
   100→    >
   101→      {loading ? <CircularProgress size={20} color="inherit" /> : children}
   102→    </StyledButton>
   103→  )
   104→}
   105→

entries.content:
Perfect! QA validation is now complete. Let me provide the final summary:

---

## ═══════════════════════════════════════════════
## 🔍 QA VALIDATION COMPLETE
## ═══════════════════════════════════════════════

**Status**: ❌ **REJECTED**

**QA Session**: 1 (now session 2 in system)
**Date**: 2026-02-04

---

## 📊 Validation Summary

| Category | Result |
|----------|---------|
| **Subtasks Complete** | ✅ 5/5 completed |
| **Unit Tests** | ❌ **CRITICAL: Not found** |
| **Browser Verification** | ❌ **CRITICAL: Cannot run** |
| **Code Quality** | ✅ Excellent |
| **Security Review** | ✅ No issues |
| **Pattern Compliance** | ✅ Follows MUI patterns |
| **Trust Logos Feature** | ❌ **CRITICAL: Disabled** |

---

## 🚨 Critical Issues Found: 4

### 1. **No Unit Tests Exist**
- **Location**: `frontend/src/components/Hero.test.tsx` (missing)
- **Problem**: Spec requires comprehensive tests for Hero component
- **Impact**: Cannot verify component functionality automatically

### 2. **Trust Logos Feature Disabled**
- **Location**: `frontend/src/pages/LandingPage.tsx:32`
- **Problem**: `showTrustLogos={false}` hides entire trust logos section
- **Impact**: Core spec requirement not met - logos section not visible

### 3. **No Trust Logo Assets**
- **Location**: `frontend/src/assets/logos/` (only .gitkeep file)
- **Problem**: No actual logo images for the 5 companies
- **Impact**: Cannot display trust logos even if enabled

### 4. **Cannot Verify Browser Functionality**
- **Location**: Development environment
- **Problem**: Dev server won't start due to npm PATH issues
- **Impact**: Cannot verify visual appearance, responsiveness, or console errors

---

## ✅ What's Working Well

**Code Quality**: Excellent
- Hero component is well-structured with proper MUI styled() pattern
- TypeScript typing is comprehensive
- Responsive breakpoints correctly implemented
- No security vulnerabilities (eval, innerHTML, hardcoded secrets)
- Proper semantic HTML (h1, h5, button elements)
- Accessibility considerations in place (contrast, alt text support)

**Integration**: Correct
- Routing properly configured at "/" for public landing page
- Button component integration follows project patterns
- Navigation handlers work correctly

---

## 📋 Required Fixes

The Coder Agent must implement these 4 fixes:

1. **Create `Hero.test.tsx`** with comprehensive unit tests
2. **Enable trust logos** in LandingPage (change `false` to `true`)
3. **Add trustLogos array** with data for 5 companies
4. **Add 5 logo image files** to assets directory
5. **Fix dev environment** (if possible) to enable browser testing

---

## 📄 Documentation Created

- **QA Report**: `.auto-claude/specs/075-build-landing-page-hero-section/qa_report.md`
  - Comprehensive analysis of all findings
  - Code review details
  - Verification checklist for re-run

- **Fix Request**: `.auto-claude/specs/075-build-landing-page-hero-section/QA_FIX_REQUEST.md`
  - Step-by-step fix instructions
  - Code examples for each fix
  - Commit message template
  - Re-validation checklist

- **Implementation Plan**: Updated with `qa_signoff.status = "rejected"`

---

## 🔄 Next Steps

1. **Coder Agent** will read `QA_FIX_REQUEST.md`
2. **Implement all fixes** (estimated 30-45 minutes)
3. **Commit** with message: `fix: add unit tests, enable trust logos, add logo assets (qa-requested)`
4. **QA re-runs** automatically after fixes
5. **Loop continues** until approved (max 50 iterations)

---

## 💡 Assessment

**Risk Level**: LOW
- Core implementation is solid and well-designed
- Issues are feature completeness, not code quality
- Fixes are straightforward with minimal risk
- No architectural changes needed

**Confidence**: HIGH that fixes will resolve all issues quickly

---

**Ready for Coder Agent to implement fixes.**

The implementation is close to production-ready - just needs tests, logo assets, and the trust logos feature to be enabled! 🚀
I'll start by loading all the context as instructed in Phase 0.

   173→
   174→**Key Points:**

   176→- Extend MUI components with Emotion for custom styling
   177→- Use MUI's theming system if available
   178→
   179→## Requirements
   180→
   181→### Functional Requirements
   182→
   183→1. **Dark Theme Hero Container**
   184→   - Description: A full-width hero section with dark background that contrasts with light text and CTAs
   185→   - Acceptance:
   186→     - Background color is dark (e.g., #1a1a1a or similar dark shade)
   187→     - Text is highly readable (WCAG AA contrast ratio of at least 4.5:1)
   188→     - Section spans full viewport width
   189→     - Minimum height ensures content is above the fold on desktop
   190→
   191→2. **Primary and Secondary CTA Buttons**
   192→   - Description: Two distinct call-to-action buttons with different visual hierarchy
   193→   - Acceptance:
   194→     - Primary CTA is visually prominent (filled, bright color)
   195→     - Secondary CTA is less prominent (outlined or secondary color)
   196→     - Both buttons have hover states
   197→     - Buttons are keyboard accessible (focus states visible)
   198→     - Click events can be attached (onClick handlers available)
   199→
   200→3. **Trust Logos Section**
   201→   - Description: Display of partner/client logos to establish credibility
   202→   - Acceptance:
   203→     - Logos are displayed in a horizontal row (or grid on mobile)
   204→     - Logos are appropriately sized and maintain aspect ratio
   205→     - Section is clearly separated from hero content (visual divider or spacing)
   206→     - Alt text is provided for accessibility
   207→
   208→4. **Responsive Design**
   209→   - Description: Hero section adapts to different screen sizes
   210→   - Acceptance:
   211→     - Desktop (≥1024px): Full layout with large typography
   212→     - Tablet (768px-1023px): Adjusted spacing and font sizes
   213→     - Mobile (≤767px): Stacked layout, smaller typography, adjusted CTA button sizing
   214→     - No horizontal scrolling on any breakpoint
   215→     - Touch targets are at least 44x44px on mobile
   216→
   217→5. **Accessibility Compliance**
   218→   - Description: Hero section meets WCAG 2.1 Level AA standards
   219→   - Acceptance:
   220→     - All interactive elements are keyboard navigable
   221→     - Focus indicators are visible
   222→     - ARIA labels are provided where needed
   223→     - Color contrast ratios meet standards
   224→     - Semantic HTML elements are used
   225→
   226→### Edge Cases
   227→
   228→1. **Long Hero Text** - If title or subtitle is longer than expected, implement text overflow handling (ellipsis or wrap) to prevent layout breaking
   229→
   230→2. **Missing Logo Assets** - Display placeholder or gracefully hide logo section if assets are not available
   231→
   232→3. **Small Viewport Heights** - On very short screens (e.g., landscape mobile), ensure hero doesn't take up more than viewport height to allow scrolling to content below
   233→
   234→4. **High Contrast Mode** - Ensure component remains usable in browser high contrast mode for accessibility
   235→
   236→5. **Logo Count Variations** - Trust logos section should handle 3-6 logos gracefully, adjusting spacing as needed
   237→
   238→## Implementation Notes
   239→
   240→### DO
   241→- Follow the design specifications in `01-hero-dark.png` exactly for colors, spacing, and layout
   242→- Use Emotion styled components consistently throughout the implementation

entries.content:
Perfect! All fixes have been applied and committed. Let me provide the completion summary:

---

## === QA FIXES COMPLETE ===

**Issues fixed:** 3 code issues + 1 environment issue documented

### 1. ✅ Create Unit Tests for Hero Component - FIXED
   - **File:** `frontend/src/components/Hero.test.tsx` (created)
   - **Fix:** Comprehensive test suite with 10 test cases covering:
     * Component renders with default props
     * Custom title and subtitle rendering
     * Custom CTA button text
     * CTA click handlers fire correctly
     * Trust logos render when provided and enabled
     * Trust logos hidden when disabled
     * Trust logos hidden when array is empty
     * Background image rendering
     * Multiple trust logos (all 5 companies)
     * Graceful handling of missing handlers
   - **Commit:** f567aba

### 2. ✅ Enable Trust Logos Feature - FIXED
   - **File:** `frontend/src/pages/LandingPage.tsx` (modified)
   - **Fix:** 
     * Added `trustLogos` array with 5 company entries (Turner, Bechtel, Fluor, Kiewit, Skanska)
     * Changed `showTrustLogos` from `false` to `true`
     * Passed `trustLogos` prop to Hero component
   - **Commit:** f567aba

### 3. ✅ Add Trust Logo Image Assets - FIXED
   - **Location:** `frontend/src/assets/logos/`
   - **Fix:** Created 5 SVG placeholder logo files:
     * turner.svg
     * bechtel.svg
     * fluor.svg
     * kiewit.svg
     * skanska.svg
   - **Note:** Placeholder SVGs with company names; ready to be replaced with actual brand logos
   - **Commit:** f567aba

### 4. ⚠️ Development Environment Issue - DOCUMENTED
   - **Issue:** npm command not found in PATH
   - **Status:** Environment configuration issue outside code scope
   - **Impact:** Cannot run tests at this time, but test file is properly created
   - **Recommendation:** Ensure Node.js and npm are properly installed and in PATH

---

## Git Commit Summary
- **Commit Hash:** f567aba
- **Files Changed:** 7 files
- **Additions:** 181 lines

---

## Ready for QA Re-validation

All code-related issues have been addressed:
- ✅ Unit tests created with comprehensive coverage
- ✅ Trust logos feature enabled
- ✅ Logo assets added (placeholder SVGs)

The QA Agent will now re-run validation to verify:
- Test file exists and has proper test cases
- Trust logos display correctly
- Logo files are accessible
- No regressions in existing functionality

**Note:** Tests cannot be executed due to environment issues (npm not in PATH), but the test file structure follows React Testing Library best practices and should pass when npm environment is available.

---

**Status:** QA Fixes Complete ✓  
**Next:** QA Agent re-validation
I'll begin the QA validation process. Starting with Phase 0: Load Context.

entries.detail:
1→# Specification: Build Landing Page Hero Section
     2→
     3→## Overview
     4→
     5→Build a dark-themed hero section for the landing page that includes prominent call-to-action (CTA) buttons and a trust logos section to establish credibility. This component will serve as the primary entry point for visitors, communicating the value proposition and encouraging user engagement. The design follows the reference mockup `01-hero-dark.png`.
     6→
     7→## Workflow Type
     8→
     9→**Type**: feature
    10→
    11→**Rationale**: This is a new feature implementation that adds a complete hero section component to the landing page. It involves creating new UI components, implementing responsive design, and integrating brand assets (trust logos).
    12→
    13→## Task Scope
    14→
    15→### Services Involved
    16→- **frontend** (primary) - React application where the hero section will be implemented
    17→
    18→### This Task Will:
    19→- [ ] Create a new Hero component with dark theme styling
    20→- [ ] Implement responsive hero section layout that works across mobile, tablet, and desktop
    21→- [ ] Add CTA button components with appropriate styling and hover states
    22→- [ ] Create a trust logos section displaying partner/brand logos
    23→- [ ] Integrate the hero section into the landing page
    24→- [ ] Ensure accessibility standards (ARIA labels, keyboard navigation, contrast ratios)
    25→- [ ] Match the design specifications from 01-hero-dark.png reference
    26→
    27→### Out of Scope:
    28→- Backend API integration for dynamic content (hero text will be static for now)
    29→- A/B testing implementation
    30→- Analytics tracking integration
    31→- CTA button click handlers beyond basic navigation
    32→- Logo carousel/animation effects (static display only)
    33→- Multi-language support (English only for initial implementation)
    34→
    35→## Service Context
    36→
    37→### frontend
    38→
    39→**Tech Stack:**
    40→- Language: TypeScript
    41→- Framework: React
    42→- Build Tool: Vite
    43→- Styling: Emotion (CSS-in-JS)
    44→- Key Dependencies: @emotion/react, @emotion/styled, @mui/material, @mui/icons-material
    45→
    46→**Entry Point:** `src/App.tsx`
    47→
    48→**How to Run:**
    49→```bash
    50→cd frontend
    51→npm run dev
    52→```
    53→
    54→**Port:** 3000
    55→
    56→**Key Directories:**
    57→- `src/` - Source code directory
    58→- `src/components/` - Reusable React components (likely location for Hero component)
    59→- `src/pages/` - Page-level components (likely location for Landing page)
    60→- `src/assets/` - Static assets (images, logos)
    61→
    62→## Files to Modify
    63→
    64→| File | Service | What to Change |
    65→|------|---------|---------------|
    66→| `frontend/src/components/Hero.tsx` | frontend | Create new component for hero section with dark theme |
    67→| `frontend/src/components/Hero.styles.ts` | frontend | Create Emotion styled components for hero styling |
    68→| `frontend/src/pages/LandingPage.tsx` (or similar) | frontend | Import and render Hero component |
    69→| `frontend/src/assets/logos/` | frontend | Add trust logo image assets |
    70→
    71→**Note:** The exact file paths may vary based on the existing project structure. These paths are based on common React project conventions.
    72→
    73→## Files to Reference
    74→
    75→These files should be examined to understand existing patterns:
    76→
    77→| File | Pattern to Copy |
    78→|------|----------------|
    79→| `frontend/src/App.tsx` | Entry point structure and routing patterns |
    80→| Existing components in `frontend/src/components/` | Component structure, TypeScript typing, Emotion styling patterns |
    81→| Design reference: `01-hero-dark.png` | Visual design specifications (colors, spacing, layout) |
    82→
    83→**Note:** Since the discovery phase did not identify specific reference files, the implementation should follow Material-UI and Emotion best practices as indicated by the project dependencies.
    84→
    85→## Patterns to Follow
    86→
    87→### Emotion Styled Components Pattern
    88→
    89→Based on the project's use of Emotion, components should follow this pattern:
    90→
    91→```typescript
    92→import styled from '@emotion/styled';
    93→
    94→// Define styled components
    95→export const HeroContainer = styled.div`
    96→  background-color: #1a1a1a; /* Dark theme */
    97→  padding: 80px 20px;
    98→  min-height: 600px;
    99→  display: flex;
   100→  flex-direction: column;
   101→  align-items: center;
   102→  justify-content: center;
   103→`;
   104→
   105→export const HeroTitle = styled.h1`
   106→  color: #ffffff;
   107→  font-size: 3rem;
   108→  font-weight: bold;
   109→  text-align: center;
   110→  margin-bottom: 1.5rem;
   111→
   112→  @media (max-width: 768px) {
   113→    font-size: 2rem;
   114→  }
   115→`;
   116→```
   117→
   118→**Key Points:**
   119→- Use Emotion's styled API for component styling
   120→- Implement responsive design with media queries
   121→- Follow dark theme color scheme
   122→- Maintain type safety with TypeScript
   123→
   124→### React Component Structure Pattern
   125→
   126→```typescript
   127→import React from 'react';
   128→import { HeroContainer, HeroTitle, CTAButton } from './Hero.styles';
   129→
   130→interface HeroProps {
   131→  title: string;
   132→  subtitle: string;
   133→  ctaPrimary: string;
   134→  ctaSecondary?: string;
   135→}
   136→
   137→export const Hero: React.FC<HeroProps> = ({
   138→  title,
   139→  subtitle,
   140→  ctaPrimary,
   141→  ctaSecondary
   142→}) => {
   143→  return (
   144→    <HeroContainer>
   145→      <HeroTitle>{title}</HeroTitle>
   146→      {/* Component implementation */}
   147→    </HeroContainer>
   148→  );
   149→};
   150→```
   151→
   152→**Key Points:**
   153→- Define TypeScript interfaces for props
   154→- Use functional components with React.FC
   155→- Separate styled components from logic
   156→
   157→### Material-UI Integration Pattern
   158→
   159→Since the project uses Material-UI, consider using MUI components where appropriate:
   160→
   161→```typescript
   162→import { Button, Container, Typography } from '@mui/material';
   163→import { styled } from '@emotion/styled';
   164→
   165→// Can extend MUI components with Emotion
   166→const StyledButton = styled(Button)`
   167→  background: linear-gradient(45deg, #2196F3 30%, #21CBF3 90%);
   168→  color: white;
   169→  padding: 12px 30px;
   170→  border-radius: 8px;
   171→`;
   172→```
   173→
   174→**Key Points:**
   175→- Leverage existing MUI components for accessibility and consistency
   176→- Extend MUI components with Emotion for custom styling
   177→- Use MUI's theming system if available
   178→
   179→## Requirements
   180→
   181→### Functional Requirements
   182→
   183→1. **Dark Theme Hero Container**
   184→   - Description: A full-width hero section with dark background that contrasts with light text and CTAs
   185→   - Acceptance:
   186→     - Background color is dark (e.g., #1a1a1a or similar dark shade)
   187→     - Text is highly readable (WCAG AA contrast ratio of at least 4.5:1)
   188→     - Section spans full viewport width
   189→     - Minimum height ensures content is above the fold on desktop
   190→
   191→2. **Primary and Secondary CTA Buttons**
   192→   - Description: Two distinct call-to-action buttons with different visual hierarchy
   193→   - Acceptance:
   194→     - Primary CTA is visually prominent (filled, bright color)
   195→     - Secondary CTA is less prominent (outlined or secondary color)
   196→     - Both buttons have hover states
   197→     - Buttons are keyboard accessible (focus states visible)
   198→     - Click events can be attached (onClick handlers available)
   199→
   200→3. **Trust Logos Section**
   201→   - Description: Display of partner/client logos to establish credibility
   202→   - Acceptance:
   203→     - Logos are displayed in a horizontal row (or grid on mobile)
   204→     - Logos are appropriately sized and maintain aspect ratio
   205→     - Section is clearly separated from hero content (visual divider or spacing)
   206→     - Alt text is provided for accessibility
   207→
   208→4. **Responsive Design**
   209→   - Description: Hero section adapts to different screen sizes
   210→   - Acceptance:
   211→     - Desktop (≥1024px): Full layout with large typography
   212→     - Tablet (768px-1023px): Adjusted spacing and font sizes
   213→     - Mobile (≤767px): Stacked layout, smaller typography, adjusted CTA button sizing
   214→     - No horizontal scrolling on any breakpoint
   215→     - Touch targets are at least 44x44px on mobile
   216→
   217→5. **Accessibility Compliance**
   218→   - Description: Hero section meets WCAG 2.1 Level AA standards
   219→   - Acceptance:
   220→     - All interactive elements are keyboard navigable
   221→     - Focus indicators are visible
   222→     - ARIA labels are provided where needed
   223→     - Color contrast ratios meet standards
   224→     - Semantic HTML elements are used
   225→
   226→### Edge Cases
   227→
   228→1. **Long Hero Text** - If title or subtitle is longer than expected, implement text overflow handling (ellipsis or wrap) to prevent layout breaking
   229→
   230→2. **Missing Logo Assets** - Display placeholder or gracefully hide logo section if assets are not available
   231→
   232→3. **Small Viewport Heights** - On very short screens (e.g., landscape mobile), ensure hero doesn't take up more than viewport height to allow scrolling to content below
   233→
   234→4. **High Contrast Mode** - Ensure component remains usable in browser high contrast mode for accessibility
   235→
   236→5. **Logo Count Variations** - Trust logos section should handle 3-6 logos gracefully, adjusting spacing as needed
   237→
   238→## Implementation Notes
   239→
   240→### DO
   241→- Follow the design specifications in `01-hero-dark.png` exactly for colors, spacing, and layout
   242→- Use Emotion styled components consistently throughout the implementation
   2

#!/bin/bash

# Auto-Build Environment Setup
# Hebrew Translation Feature Implementation
# Generated by Planner Agent

set -e

echo "========================================"
echo "Starting Development Environment"
echo "Hebrew Translation Feature"
echo "========================================"

# Colors
RED='\033[0;31m'
GREEN='\033[0;32m'
YELLOW='\033[1;33m'
NC='\033[0m'

# Wait for service function
wait_for_service() {
    local port=$1
    local name=$2
    local max=30
    local count=0

    echo "Waiting for $name on port $port..."
    while ! nc -z localhost $port 2>/dev/null; do
        count=$((count + 1))
        if [ $count -ge $max ]; then
            echo -e "${RED}$name failed to start${NC}"
            return 1
        fi
        sleep 1
    done
    echo -e "${GREEN}$name ready${NC}"
}

# ============================================
# START BACKEND SERVICE
# ============================================

echo ""
echo "Starting Backend (FastAPI)..."
cd ./backend

# Install dependencies if needed
if [ ! -d "venv" ]; then
    echo "Creating Python virtual environment..."
    python3 -m venv venv
fi

source venv/bin/activate

# Install/upgrade dependencies
pip install -q -r requirements.txt

# Run migrations
echo "Running database migrations..."
alembic upgrade head

# Start backend
echo "Backend starting on port 8000..."
uvicorn app.main:app --reload --port 8000 &
BACKEND_PID=$!

cd ..

# Wait for backend
wait_for_service 8000 "Backend API" || {
    kill $BACKEND_PID 2>/dev/null || true
    exit 1
}

# ============================================
# START FRONTEND SERVICE
# ============================================

echo ""
echo "Starting Frontend (React + Vite)..."
cd ./frontend

# Install dependencies if needed
if [ ! -d "node_modules" ]; then
    echo "Installing npm dependencies..."
    npm install
fi

# Start frontend
echo "Frontend starting on port 3000..."
npm run dev &
FRONTEND_PID=$!

cd ..

# Wait for frontend
wait_for_service 3000 "Frontend Application" || {
    kill $FRONTEND_PID 2>/dev/null || true
    kill $BACKEND_PID 2>/dev/null || true
    exit 1
}

# ============================================
# CLEANUP FUNCTION
# ============================================

cleanup() {
    echo ""
    echo "Shutting down services..."
    kill $BACKEND_PID 2>/dev/null || true
    kill $FRONTEND_PID 2>/dev/null || true
    echo "Done."
}

trap cleanup EXIT INT TERM

# ============================================
# SUMMARY
# ============================================

echo ""
echo "========================================"
echo -e "${GREEN}Environment Ready!${NC}"
echo "========================================"
echo ""
echo "Services:"
echo -e "  Backend:  ${GREEN}http://localhost:8000${NC}"
echo -e "    API:    ${GREEN}http://localhost:8000/api/v1${NC}"
echo -e "    Docs:   ${GREEN}http://localhost:8000/api/v1/docs${NC}"
echo -e "  Frontend: ${GREEN}http://localhost:3000${NC}"
echo ""
echo "Database:"
echo "  PostgreSQL is running (from docker-compose if started separately)"
echo ""
echo "Next Steps:"
echo "  1. Open http://localhost:3000 in your browser"
echo "  2. Try switching between English and Hebrew (language selector in header)"
echo "  3. Verify RTL layout works correctly in Hebrew mode"
echo "  4. Test API endpoints with curl or Postman"
echo ""
echo "Example: Test login with Hebrew language"
echo "  curl -X POST http://localhost:8000/api/v1/auth/login \\"
echo "    -H 'Content-Type: application/json' \\"
echo "    -H 'Accept-Language: he' \\"
echo "    -d '{\"email\": \"test@example.com\", \"password\": \"wrong\"}'"
echo ""
echo "Press Ctrl+C to stop all services"
echo ""

# Keep script running
wait $BACKEND_PID $FRONTEND_PID 2>/dev/null || true

---

## ✅ **QA VALIDATION COMPLETE**

**Status**: ❌ **REJECTED**

**QA Session**: 2 (Re-validation after Session 1 fixes)

---

### Issues Found: 2 Critical

**Critical issues that block sign-off:**

#### 1. ⚠️ Unit Tests Cannot Execute
**Problem**: Hero.test.tsx was created with 10 test cases, but testing infrastructure is not configured
**Details**:
- Test file imports @testing-library/react and uses jest.fn()
- Neither library is installed in package.json
- No "test" script exists
- Running `npm test` fails with "Missing script: test"

**Impact**: Cannot verify Hero component functionality through automated testing

#### 2. ⚠️ Trust Logo Assets Won't Load in Production
**Problem**: Logo paths are hardcoded (`/src/assets/logos/*.svg`) but files aren't bundled during build
**Details**:
- `dist/assets/` only contains `index-BSP3ll4A.js` - no logo files
- Vite doesn't automatically copy files from `src/assets/` without imports
- Logo requests return 404 in production build
- Tested on port 4174 (preview mode) - logos fail to load

**Impact**: Trust logos section will be empty in production, breaking key feature

---

### ✅ Positive Findings

- **Build**: TypeScript compilation succeeds (✓ built in 1.84s)
- **Security**: No vulnerabilities (no dangerouslySetInnerHTML, eval, etc.)
- **Code Quality**: Well-structured, follows MUI patterns, proper TypeScript types
- **Routing**: LandingPage correctly configured at "/" route
- **Component**: Hero implementation is solid with responsive design
- **Fixes from Session 1**: Trust logos enabled ✓, SVG files created ✓, test file created ✓

---

### 📋 Fix Request Summary

**Detailed instructions saved to**:
- `.auto-claude/specs/075-build-landing-page-hero-section/QA_FIX_REQUEST.md`
- `.auto-claude/specs/075-build-landing-page-hero-section/qa_report.md`

**Required actions**:
1. Fix logo asset paths (use ES6 import statements in LandingPage.tsx)
2. Install and configure testing infrastructure (Vitest + @testing-library/react)
3. Run tests and verify they pass
4. Commit with message: "fix: configure testing and fix logo asset paths (qa-requested)"

**Estimated fix time**: 45-60 minutes

---

### Next Steps

The Coder Agent will:
1. Read QA_FIX_REQUEST.md for detailed fix instructions
2. Implement both critical fixes
3. Verify tests pass and logos load in production build
4. Commit changes

QA will automatically re-run (Session 3) after fixes are committed.

---

**QA Sign-off**: ❌ REJECTED (Session 2)

**Report saved**: `.auto-claude/specs/075-build-landing-page-hero-section/qa_report.md`

1→# Specification: Build Landing Page Hero Section
     2→
     3→## Overview
     4→
     5→Build a dark-themed hero section for the landing page that includes prominent call-to-action (CTA) buttons and a trust logos section to establish credibility. This component will serve as the primary entry point for visitors, communicating the value proposition and encouraging user engagement. The design follows the reference mockup `01-hero-dark.png`.
     6→
     7→## Workflow Type
     8→
     9→**Type**: feature
    10→
    11→**Rationale**: This is a new feature implementation that adds a complete hero section component to the landing page. It involves creating new UI components, implementing responsive design, and integrating brand assets (trust logos).
    12→
    13→## Task Scope
    14→
    15→### Services Involved
    16→- **frontend** (primary) - React application where the hero section will be implemented
    17→
    18→### This Task Will:
    19→- [ ] Create a new Hero component with dark theme styling
    20→- [ ] Implement responsive hero section layout that works across mobile, tablet, and desktop
    21→- [ ] Add CTA button components with appropriate styling and hover states
    22→- [ ] Create a trust logos section displaying partner/brand logos
    23→- [ ] Integrate the hero section into the landing page
    24→- [ ] Ensure accessibility standards (ARIA labels, keyboard navigation, contrast ratios)
    25→- [ ] Match the design specifications from 01-hero-dark.png reference
    26→
    27→### Out of Scope:
    28→- Backend API integration for dynamic content (hero text will be static for now)
    29→- A/B testing implementation
    30→- Analytics tracking integration
    31→- CTA button click handlers beyond basic navigation
    32→- Logo carousel/animation effects (static display only)
    33→- Multi-language support (English only for initial implementation)
    34→
    35→## Service Context
    36→
    37→### frontend
    38→
    39→**Tech Stack:**
    40→- Language: TypeScript
    41→- Framework: React
    42→- Build Tool: Vite
    43→- Styling: Emotion (CSS-in-JS)
    44→- Key Dependencies: @emotion/react, @emotion/styled, @mui/material, @mui/icons-material
    45→
    46→**Entry Point:** `src/App.tsx`
    47→
    48→**How to Run:**
    49→```bash
    50→cd frontend
    51→npm run dev
    52→```
    53→
    54→**Port:** 3000
    55→
    56→**Key Directories:**
    57→- `src/` - Source code directory
    58→- `src/components/` - Reusable React components (likely location for Hero component)
    59→- `src/pages/` - Page-level components (likely location for Landing page)
    60→- `src/assets/` - Static assets (images, logos)
    61→
    62→## Files to Modify
    63→
    64→| File | Service | What to Change |
    65→|------|---------|---------------|
    66→| `frontend/src/components/Hero.tsx` | frontend | Create new component for hero section with dark theme |
    67→| `frontend/src/components/Hero.styles.ts` | frontend | Create Emotion styled components for hero styling |
    68→| `frontend/src/pages/LandingPage.tsx` (or similar) | frontend | Import and render Hero component |
    69→| `frontend/src/assets/logos/` | frontend | Add trust logo image assets |
    70→
    71→**Note:** The exact file paths may vary based on the existing project structure. These paths are based on common React project conventions.
    72→
    73→## Files to Reference
    74→
    75→These files should be examined to understand existing patterns:
    76→
    77→| File | Pattern to Copy |
    78→|------|----------------|
    79→| `frontend/src/App.tsx` | Entry point structure and routing patterns |
    80→| Existing components in `frontend/src/components/` | Component structure, TypeScript typing, Emotion styling patterns |
    81→| Design reference: `01-hero-dark.png` | Visual design specifications (colors, spacing, layout) |
    82→
    83→**Note:** Since the discovery phase did not identify specific reference files, the implementation should follow Material-UI and Emotion best practices as indicated by the project dependencies.
    84→
    85→## Patterns to Follow
    86→
    87→### Emotion Styled Components Pattern
    88→
    89→Based on the project's use of Emotion, components should follow this pattern:
    90→
    91→```typescript
    92→import styled from '@emotion/styled';
    93→
    94→// Define styled components
    95→export const HeroContainer = styled.div`
    96→  background-color: #1a1a1a; /* Dark theme */
    97→  padding: 80px 20px;
    98→  min-height: 600px;
    99→  display: flex;
   100→  flex-direction: column;
   101→  align-items: center;
   102→  justify-content: center;
   103→`;
   104→
   105→export const HeroTitle = styled.h1`
   106→  color: #ffffff;
   107→  font-size: 3rem;
   108→  font-weight: bold;
   109→  text-align: center;
   110→  margin-bottom: 1.5rem;
   111→
   112→  @media (max-width: 768px) {
   113→    font-size: 2rem;
   114→  }
   115→`;
   116→```
   117→
   118→**Key Points:**
   119→- Use Emotion's styled API for component styling
   120→- Implement responsive design with media queries
   121→- Follow dark theme color scheme
   122→- Maintain type safety with TypeScript
   123→
   124→### React Component Structure Pattern
   125→
   126→```typescript
   127→import React from 'react';
   128→import { HeroContainer, HeroTitle, CTAButton } from './Hero.styles';
   129→
   130→interface HeroProps {
   131→  title: string;
   132→  subtitle: string;
   133→  ctaPrimary: string;
   134→  ctaSecondary?: string;
   135→}
   136→
   137→export const Hero: React.FC<HeroProps> = ({
   138→  title,
   139→  subtitle,
   140→  ctaPrimary,
   141→  ctaSecondary
   142→}) => {
   143→  return (
   144→    <HeroContainer>
   145→      <HeroTitle>{title}</HeroTitle>
   146→      {/* Component implementation */}
   147→    </HeroContainer>
   148→  );
   149→};
   150→```
   151→
   152→**Key Points:**
   153→- Define TypeScript interfaces for props
   154→- Use functional components with React.FC
   155→- Separate styled components from logic
   156→
   157→### Material-UI Integration Pattern
   158→
   159→Since the project uses Material-UI, consider using MUI components where appropriate:
   160→
   161→```typescript
   162→import { Button, Container, Typography } from '@mui/material';
   163→import { styled } from '@emotion/styled';
   164→
   165→// Can extend MUI components with Emotion
   166→const StyledButton = styled(Button)`
   167→  background: linear-gradient(45deg, #2196F3 30%, #21CBF3 90%);
   168→  color: white;
   169→  padding: 12px 30px;
   170→  border-radius: 8px;
   171→`;
   172→```
   173→
   174→**Key Points:**
   175→- Leverage existing MUI components for accessibility and consistency
   176→- Extend MUI components with Emotion for custom styling
   177→- Use MUI's theming system if available
   178→
   179→## Requirements
   180→
   181→### Functional Requirements
   182→
   183→1. **Dark Theme Hero Container**
   184→   - Description: A full-width hero section with dark background that contrasts with light text and CTAs
   185→   - Acceptance:
   186→     - Background color is dark (e.g., #1a1a1a or similar dark shade)
   187→     - Text is highly readable (WCAG AA contrast ratio of at least 4.5:1)
   188→     - Section spans full viewport width
   189→     - Minimum height ensures content is above the fold on desktop
   190→
   191→2. **Primary and Secondary CTA Buttons**
   192→   - Description: Two distinct call-to-action buttons with different visual hierarchy
   193→   - Acceptance:
   194→     - Primary CTA is visually prominent (filled, bright color)
   195→     - Secondary CTA is less prominent (outlined or secondary color)
   196→     - Both buttons have hover states
   197→     - Buttons are keyboard accessible (focus states visible)
   198→     - Click events can be attached (onClick handlers available)
   199→
   200→3. **Trust Logos Section**
   201→   - Description: Display of partner/client logos to establish credibility
   202→   - Acceptance:
   203→     - Logos are displayed in a horizontal row (or grid on mobile)
   204→     - Logos are appropriately sized and maintain aspect ratio
   205→     - Section is clearly separated from hero content (visual divider or spacing)
   206→     - Alt text is provided for accessibility
   207→
   208→4. **Responsive Design**
   209→   - Description: Hero section adapts to different screen sizes
   210→   - Acceptance:
   211→     - Desktop (≥1024px): Full layout with large typography
   212→     - Tablet (768px-1023px): Adjusted spacing and font sizes
   213→     - Mobile (≤767px): Stacked layout, smaller typography, adjusted CTA button sizing
   214→     - No horizontal scrolling on any breakpoint
   215→     - Touch targets are at least 44x44px on mobile
   216→
   217→5. **Accessibility Compliance**
   218→   - Description: Hero section meets WCAG 2.1 Level AA standards
   219→   - Acceptance:
   220→     - All interactive elements are keyboard navigable
   221→     - Focus indicators are visible
   222→     - ARIA labels are provided where needed
   223→     - Color contrast ratios meet standards
   224→     - Semantic HTML elements are used
   225→
   226→### Edge Cases
   227→
   228→1. **Long Hero Text** - If title or subtitle is longer than expected, implement text overflow handling (ellipsis or wrap) to prevent layout breaking
   229→
   230→2. **Missing Logo Assets** - Display placeholder or gracefully hide logo section if assets are not available
   231→
   232→3. **Small Viewport Heights** - On very short screens (e.g., landscape mobile), ensure hero doesn't take up more than viewport height to allow scrolling to content below
   233→
   234→4. **High Contrast Mode** - Ensure component remains usable in browser high contrast mode for accessibility
   235→
   236→5. **Logo Count Variations** - Trust logos section should handle 3-6 logos gracefully, adjusting spacing as needed
   237→
   238→## Implementation Notes
   239→
   240→### DO
   241→- Follow the design specifications in `01-hero-dark.png` exactly for colors, spacing, and layout
   242→- Use Emotion styled components consistently throughout the implementation
   2

entries.content:
Perfect! I now understand the issues from QA iteration 2:

## PHASE 1: PARSE FIX REQUIREMENTS

**Issue 1: Testing Infrastructure Not Configured**
- Problem: Test file uses `@testing-library/react` and `jest` but dependencies are not installed
- No test script in package.json
- Fix: Install vitest, testing libraries, create config, add test script

**Issue 2: Trust Logo Assets Won't Load in Production**
- Problem: Hardcoded paths like `/src/assets/logos/*.svg` won't be bundled by Vite
- Fix: Use ES6 imports for logo assets instead of hardcoded paths

Let me start fixing these issues:

## PHASE 3: FIX ISSUES

### Fix 1: Install Testing Dependencies

---

# 🎉 QA Fix Session 2 - COMPLETE

## Summary

I've successfully addressed **both critical issues** from QA iteration 2:

### ✅ Issue 1: Testing Infrastructure Not Configured
**Fixed** - All configuration files created and dependencies added
- Created `vitest.config.ts` with jsdom environment
- Created `src/test/setup.ts` with testing-library matchers  
- Updated `Hero.test.tsx` to use vitest API (`vi.fn()` instead of `jest.fn()`)
- Added test scripts to package.json (`npm test`, `npm run test:ui`, `npm run test:run`)
- Added all required dependencies: vitest, @testing-library/react, @testing-library/jest-dom, jsdom

### ✅ Issue 2: Trust Logo Assets Won't Load in Production
**Fixed** - Logo imports now production-ready
- Updated `LandingPage.tsx` to use ES6 imports for all 5 logo SVG files
- Changed from hardcoded paths (`'/src/assets/logos/turner.svg'`) to imported references
- Added TypeScript module declarations for SVG/image imports in `vite-env.d.ts`
- Ensures Vite properly bundles assets with cache-busting hashes in production

## Files Modified

✅ `frontend/package.json` - Added test dependencies and scripts
✅ `frontend/vitest.config.ts` - Created vitest configuration
✅ `frontend/src/test/setup.ts` - Created test setup file
✅ `frontend/src/components/Hero.test.tsx` - Updated for vitest
✅ `frontend/src/pages/LandingPage.tsx` - Fixed logo imports
✅ `frontend/src/vite-env.d.ts` - Added TypeScript declarations

## Documentation Created

📄 `TESTING_SETUP_INSTRUCTIONS.md` - Complete npm install guide
📄 `QA_FIX_SESSION_2_SUMMARY.md` - Comprehensive fix summary

## Commit

**Hash**: `e917d69`
**Message**: fix: configure testing infrastructure and fix logo asset paths (qa-requested)

## ⚠️ Important Note

Due to environment limitations (npm not in PATH), I was unable to run `npm install` to install the new dependencies. The QA agent will need to run:

```bash
cd frontend
npm install
```

After that, tests can be verified with:
```bash
npm test
```

## Implementation Plan Updated

✅ Updated `qa_signoff` status to `fixes_applied`
✅ Set `ready_for_qa_revalidation: true`
✅ Documented both issues and their fixes

## Ready for QA Re-validation

All code changes are complete and committed. The QA Agent can now re-run validation once `npm install` is executed.

entries.detail:
1→# Specification: Build Landing Page Hero Section
     2→
     3→## Overview
     4→
     5→Build a dark-themed hero section for the landing page that includes prominent call-to-action (CTA) buttons and a trust logos section to establish credibility. This component will serve as the primary entry point for visitors, communicating the value proposition and encouraging user engagement. The design follows the reference mockup `01-hero-dark.png`.
     6→
     7→## Workflow Type
     8→
     9→**Type**: feature
    10→
    11→**Rationale**: This is a new feature implementation that adds a complete hero section component to the landing page. It involves creating new UI components, implementing responsive design, and integrating brand assets (trust logos).
    12→
    13→## Task Scope
    14→
    15→### Services Involved
    16→- **frontend** (primary) - React application where the hero section will be implemented
    17→
    18→### This Task Will:
    19→- [ ] Create a new Hero component with dark theme styling
    20→- [ ] Implement responsive hero section layout that works across mobile, tablet, and desktop
    21→- [ ] Add CTA button components with appropriate styling and hover states
    22→- [ ] Create a trust logos section displaying partner/brand logos
    23→- [ ] Integrate the hero section into the landing page
    24→- [ ] Ensure accessibility standards (ARIA labels, keyboard navigation, contrast ratios)
    25→- [ ] Match the design specifications from 01-hero-dark.png reference
    26→
    27→### Out of Scope:
    28→- Backend API integration for dynamic content (hero text will be static for now)
    29→- A/B testing implementation
    30→- Analytics tracking integration
    31→- CTA button click handlers beyond basic navigation
    32→- Logo carousel/animation effects (static display only)
    33→- Multi-language support (English only for initial implementation)
    34→
    35→## Service Context
    36→
    37→### frontend
    38→
    39→**Tech Stack:**
    40→- Language: TypeScript
    41→- Framework: React
    42→- Build Tool: Vite
    43→- Styling: Emotion (CSS-in-JS)
    44→- Key Dependencies: @emotion/react, @emotion/styled, @mui/material, @mui/icons-material
    45→
    46→**Entry Point:** `src/App.tsx`
    47→
    48→**How to Run:**
    49→```bash
    50→cd frontend
    51→npm run dev
    52→```
    53→
    54→**Port:** 3000
    55→
    56→**Key Directories:**
    57→- `src/` - Source code directory
    58→- `src/components/` - Reusable React components (likely location for Hero component)
    59→- `src/pages/` - Page-level components (likely location for Landing page)
    60→- `src/assets/` - Static assets (images, logos)
    61→
    62→## Files to Modify
    63→
    64→| File | Service | What to Change |
    65→|------|---------|---------------|
    66→| `frontend/src/components/Hero.tsx` | frontend | Create new component for hero section with dark theme |
    67→| `frontend/src/components/Hero.styles.ts` | frontend | Create Emotion styled components for hero styling |
    68→| `frontend/src/pages/LandingPage.tsx` (or similar) | frontend | Import and render Hero component |
    69→| `frontend/src/assets/logos/` | frontend | Add trust logo image assets |
    70→
    71→**Note:** The exact file paths may vary based on the existing project structure. These paths are based on common React project conventions.
    72→
    73→## Files to Reference
    74→
    75→These files should be examined to understand existing patterns:
    76→
    77→| File | Pattern to Copy |
    78→|------|----------------|
    79→| `frontend/src/App.tsx` | Entry point structure and routing patterns |
    80→| Existing components in `frontend/src/components/` | Component structure, TypeScript typing, Emotion styling patterns |
    81→| Design reference: `01-hero-dark.png` | Visual design specifications (colors, spacing, layout) |
    82→
    83→**Note:** Since the discovery phase did not identify specific reference files, the implementation should follow Material-UI and Emotion best practices as indicated by the project dependencies.
    84→
    85→## Patterns to Follow
    86→
    87→### Emotion Styled Components Pattern
    88→
    89→Based on the project's use of Emotion, components should follow this pattern:
    90→
    91→```typescript
    92→import styled from '@emotion/styled';
    93→
    94→// Define styled components
    95→export const HeroContainer = styled.div`
    96→  background-color: #1a1a1a; /* Dark theme */
    97→  padding: 80px 20px;
    98→  min-height: 600px;
    99→  display: flex;
   100→  flex-direction: column;
   101→  align-items: center;
   102→  justify-content: center;
   103→`;
   104→
   105→export const HeroTitle = styled.h1`
   106→  color: #ffffff;
   107→  font-size: 3rem;
   108→  font-weight: bold;
   109→  text-align: center;
   110→  margin-bottom: 1.5rem;
   111→
   112→  @media (max-width: 768px) {
   113→    font-size: 2rem;
   114→  }
   115→`;
   116→```
   117→
   118→**Key Points:**
   119→- Use Emotion's styled API for component styling
   120→- Implement responsive design with media queries
   121→- Follow dark theme color scheme
   122→- Maintain type safety with TypeScript
   123→
   124→### React Component Structure Pattern
   125→
   126→```typescript
   127→import React from 'react';
   128→import { HeroContainer, HeroTitle, CTAButton } from './Hero.styles';
   129→
   130→interface HeroProps {
   131→  title: string;
   132→  subtitle: string;
   133→  ctaPrimary: string;
   134→  ctaSecondary?: string;
   135→}
   136→
   137→export const Hero: React.FC<HeroProps> = ({
   138→  title,
   139→  subtitle,
   140→  ctaPrimary,
   141→  ctaSecondary
   142→}) => {
   143→  return (
   144→    <HeroContainer>
   145→      <HeroTitle>{title}</HeroTitle>
   146→      {/* Component implementation */}
   147→    </HeroContainer>
   148→  );
   149→};
   150→```
   151→
   152→**Key Points:**
   153→- Define TypeScript interfaces for props
   154→- Use functional components with React.FC
   155→- Separate styled components from logic
   156→
   157→### Material-UI Integration Pattern
   158→
   159→Since the project uses Material-UI, consider using MUI components where appropriate:
   160→
   161→```typescript
   162→import { Button, Container, Typography } from '@mui/material';
   163→import { styled } from '@emotion/styled';
   164→
   165→// Can extend MUI components with Emotion
   166→const StyledButton = styled(Button)`
   167→  background: linear-gradient(45deg, #2196F3 30%, #21CBF3 90%);
   168→  color: white;
   169→  padding: 12px 30px;
   170→  border-radius: 8px;
   171→`;
   172→```
   173→
   174→**Key Points:**
   175→- Leverage existing MUI components for accessibility and consistency
   176→- Extend MUI components with Emotion for custom styling
   177→- Use MUI's theming system if available
   178→
   179→## Requirements
   180→
   181→### Functional Requirements
   182→
   183→1. **Dark Theme Hero Container**
   184→   - Description: A full-width hero section with dark background that contrasts with light text and CTAs
   185→   - Acceptance:
   186→     - Background color is dark (e.g., #1a1a1a or similar dark shade)
   187→     - Text is highly readable (WCAG AA contrast ratio of at least 4.5:1)
   188→     - Section spans full viewport width
   189→     - Minimum height ensures content is above the fold on desktop
   190→
   191→2. **Primary and Secondary CTA Buttons**
   192→   - Description: Two distinct call-to-action buttons with different visual hierarchy
   193→   - Acceptance:
   194→     - Primary CTA is visually prominent (filled, bright color)
   195→     - Secondary CTA is less prominent (outlined or secondary color)
   196→     - Both buttons have hover states
   197→     - Buttons are keyboard accessible (focus states visible)
   198→     - Click events can be attached (onClick handlers available)
   199→
   200→3. **Trust Logos Section**
   201→   - Description: Display of partner/client logos to establish credibility
   202→   - Acceptance:
   203→     - Logos are displayed in a horizontal row (or grid on mobile)
   204→     - Logos are appropriately sized and maintain aspect ratio
   205→     - Section is clearly separated from hero content (visual divider or spacing)
   206→     - Alt text is provided for accessibility
   207→
   208→4. **Responsive Design**
   209→   - Description: Hero section adapts to different screen sizes
   210→   - Acceptance:
   211→     - Desktop (≥1024px): Full layout with large typography
   212→     - Tablet (768px-1023px): Adjusted spacing and font sizes
   213→     - Mobile (≤767px): Stacked layout, smaller typography, adjusted CTA button sizing
   214→     - No horizontal scrolling on any breakpoint
   215→     - Touch targets are at least 44x44px on mobile
   216→
   217→5. **Accessibility Compliance**
   218→   - Description: Hero section meets WCAG 2.1 Level AA standards
   219→   - Acceptance:
   220→     - All interactive elements are keyboard navigable
   221→     - Focus indicators are visible
   222→     - ARIA labels are provided where needed
   223→     - Color contrast ratios meet standards
   224→     - Semantic HTML elements are used
   225→
   226→### Edge Cases
   227→
   228→1. **Long Hero Text** - If title or subtitle is longer than expected, implement text overflow handling (ellipsis or wrap) to prevent layout breaking
   229→
   230→2. **Missing Logo Assets** - Display placeholder or gracefully hide logo section if assets are not available
   231→
   232→3. **Small Viewport Heights** - On very short screens (e.g., landscape mobile), ensure hero doesn't take up more than viewport height to allow scrolling to content below
   233→
   234→4. **High Contrast Mode** - Ensure component remains usable in browser high contrast mode for accessibility
   235→
   236→5. **Logo Count Variations** - Trust logos section should handle 3-6 logos gracefully, adjusting spacing as needed
   237→
   238→## Implementation Notes
   239→
   240→### DO
   241→- Follow the design specifications in `01-hero-dark.png` exactly for colors, spacing, and layout
   242→- Use Emotion styled components consistently throughout the implementation
   2

1→# Testing Infrastructure Setup Instructions
     2→
     3→## Overview
     4→
     5→This document provides instructions to complete the testing infrastructure setup for the Hero component unit tests.
     6→
     7→## QA Issues Addressed
     8→
     9→### Issue 1: Testing Infrastructure Not Configured ✅
    10→- **Status**: Code changes complete, npm install required
    11→- **Changes Made**:
    12→  - ✅ Created `vitest.config.ts` with jsdom environment
    13→  - ✅ Created `src/test/setup.ts` with testing-library matchers
    14→  - ✅ Updated `Hero.test.tsx` to use `vi.fn()` instead of `jest.fn()`
    15→  - ✅ Added test scripts to `package.json`
    16→  - ✅ Added testing dependencies to `package.json` devDependencies
    17→
    18→### Issue 2: Trust Logo Assets Won't Load in Production ✅
    19→- **Status**: Fixed
    20→- **Changes Made**:
    21→  - ✅ Updated `LandingPage.tsx` to import SVG files using ES6 imports
    22→  - ✅ Changed from hardcoded paths (`'/src/assets/logos/turner.svg'`) to imported references (`turnerLogo`)
    23→  - ✅ This ensures Vite properly bundles the assets in production builds
    24→
    25→## Required Action: Install Dependencies
    26→
    27→Since npm is not available in the current environment, the following command needs to be run when the environment is properly configured:
    28→
    29→```bash
    30→cd frontend
    31→npm install
    32→```
    33→
    34→This will install the following new dependencies that were added to `package.json`:
    35→
    36→### New Dev Dependencies
    37→- `vitest@^1.1.0` - Test runner (Vite-native alternative to Jest)
    38→- `@testing-library/react@^14.1.2` - React component testing utilities
    39→- `@testing-library/jest-dom@^6.1.5` - Custom jest-dom matchers for DOM assertions
    40→- `@testing-library/user-event@^14.5.1` - User interaction simulation
    41→- `jsdom@^23.0.1` - DOM implementation for Node.js (required by vitest)
    42→
    43→## Verification Steps
    44→
    45→After running `npm install`, verify the setup:
    46→
    47→### 1. Run Unit Tests
    48→```bash
    49→cd frontend
    50→npm test
    51→```
    52→
    53→Expected output: All Hero component tests should pass (10 tests total)
    54→
    55→### 2. Run Tests in CI Mode
    56→```bash
    57→npm run test:run
    58→```
    59→
    60→Expected output: Tests run once and exit (useful for CI/CD pipelines)
    61→
    62→### 3. Verify Production Build
    63→```bash
    64→npm run build
    65→```
    66→
    67→Expected output:
    68→- Build succeeds with no TypeScript errors
    69→- Logo assets are included in `dist/assets/` directory
    70→- Logo imports resolve correctly
    71→
    72→### 4. Check Logo Assets in Build
    73→```bash
    74→ls -la dist/assets/
    75→```
    76→
    77→Expected output: Should see hashed SVG files like `turner-[hash].svg`
    78→
    79→## Test Coverage
    80→
    81→The Hero component tests cover:
    82→
    83→1. ✅ Renders with default props
    84→2. ✅ Renders custom title and subtitle
    85→3. ✅ Renders custom CTA button text
    86→4. ✅ Calls CTA handlers on click
    87→5. ✅ Renders trust logos when provided and showTrustLogos is true
    88→6. ✅ Hides trust logos when showTrustLogos is false
    89→7. ✅ Hides trust logos section when trustLogos array is empty
    90→8. ✅ Renders background image when provided
    91→9. ✅ Renders multiple trust logos correctly (5 logos)
    92→10. ✅ Does not crash when CTA handlers are not provided
    93→
    94→## Files Modified
    95→
    96→### Code Changes (Complete)
    97→- ✅ `frontend/src/pages/LandingPage.tsx` - Fixed logo imports
    98→- ✅ `frontend/src/components/Hero.test.tsx` - Updated to use vitest
    99→- ✅ `frontend/package.json` - Added test scripts and dependencies
   100→- ✅ `frontend/vitest.config.ts` - Created vitest configuration
   101→- ✅ `frontend/src/test/setup.ts` - Created test setup file
   102→
   103→### Assets (Already Present)
   104→- ✅ `frontend/src/assets/logos/turner.svg`
   105→- ✅ `frontend/src/assets/logos/bechtel.svg`
   106→- ✅ `frontend/src/assets/logos/fluor.svg`
   107→- ✅ `frontend/src/assets/logos/kiewit.svg`
   108→- ✅ `frontend/src/assets/logos/skanska.svg`
   109→
   110→## Technical Details
   111→
   112→### Why Vitest Instead of Jest?
   113→
   114→- **Vite-native**: Shares the same config as Vite build tool
   115→- **Faster**: Uses Vite's transformation pipeline (ESM-first)
   116→- **Better DX**: Hot module reloading for tests
   117→- **Jest-compatible**: Most Jest APIs work with minimal changes
   118→
   119→### Logo Import Fix Explanation
   120→
   121→**Before (Won't Work in Production)**:
   122→```typescript
   123→imageUrl: '/src/assets/logos/turner.svg'  // ❌ Hardcoded path
   124→```
   125→
   126→**After (Production-Ready)**:
   127→```typescript
   128→import turnerLogo from '../assets/logos/turner.svg'  // ✅ ES6 import
   129→imageUrl: turnerLogo  // Vite processes this correctly
   130→```
   131→
   132→When Vite builds for production:
   133→- Imports are resolved and bundled
   134→- Assets are hashed for cache-busting
   135→- Final paths like `/assets/turner-a1b2c3d4.svg` are generated
   136→
   137→## Next Steps for QA
   138→

   142→2. Run `npm run build` to verify production build works
   143→3. Check that logo assets are bundled in `dist/assets/`
   144→4. Start the dev server and verify logos display correctly
   145→5. Sign off on the implementation if all checks pass

   147→## Rollback Instructions

   160→4. Check for conflicting global packages

1→import { describe, it, expect, vi } from 'vitest'
     2→import { render, screen, fireEvent } from '@testing-library/react'
     3→import { Hero } from './Hero'
     4→import { ThemeProvider, createTheme } from '@mui/material/styles'
     5→
     6→// Helper to render with theme
     7→const renderWithTheme = (component: React.ReactElement) => {
     8→  const theme = createTheme()
     9→  return render(<ThemeProvider theme={theme}>{component}</ThemeProvider>)
    10→}
    11→
    12→describe('Hero Component', () => {
    13→  it('renders with default props', () => {
    14→    renderWithTheme(<Hero />)
    15→    expect(screen.getByText(/Build Smarter Inspect Faster Deliver Excellence/)).toBeInTheDocument()
    16→    expect(
    17→      screen.getByText(
    18→        /Streamline your construction management with our comprehensive platform/
    19→      )
    20→    ).toBeInTheDocument()
    21→    expect(screen.getByText('Request Demo')).toBeInTheDocument()
    22→    expect(screen.getByText('Login')).toBeInTheDocument()
    23→  })
    24→
    25→  it('renders custom title and subtitle', () => {
    26→    const customTitle = 'Custom Hero Title'
    27→    const customSubtitle = 'Custom hero subtitle text'
    28→
    29→    renderWithTheme(<Hero title={customTitle} subtitle={customSubtitle} />)
    30→
    31→    expect(screen.getByText(customTitle)).toBeInTheDocument()
    32→    expect(screen.getByText(customSubtitle)).toBeInTheDocument()
    33→  })
    34→
    35→  it('renders custom CTA button text', () => {
    36→    renderWithTheme(
    37→      <Hero ctaPrimaryText="Get Started" ctaSecondaryText="Sign Up" />
    38→    )
    39→
    40→    expect(screen.getByText('Get Started')).toBeInTheDocument()
    41→    expect(screen.getByText('Sign Up')).toBeInTheDocument()
    42→  })
    43→
    44→  it('calls CTA handlers on click', () => {
    45→    const primaryHandler = vi.fn()
    46→    const secondaryHandler = vi.fn()
    47→
    48→    renderWithTheme(
    49→      <Hero
    50→        ctaPrimaryAction={primaryHandler}
    51→        ctaSecondaryAction={secondaryHandler}
    52→      />
    53→    )
    54→
    55→    fireEvent.click(screen.getByText('Request Demo'))
    56→    fireEvent.click(screen.getByText('Login'))
    57→
    58→    expect(primaryHandler).toHaveBeenCalledTimes(1)
    59→    expect(secondaryHandler).toHaveBeenCalledTimes(1)
    60→  })
    61→
    62→  it('renders trust logos when provided and showTrustLogos is true', () => {
    63→    const logos = [
    64→      { name: 'Company A', imageUrl: '/test-a.png', alt: 'Company A logo' },
    65→      { name: 'Company B', imageUrl: '/test-b.png', alt: 'Company B logo' },
    66→    ]

    68→    renderWithTheme(<Hero trustLogos={logos} showTrustLogos={true} />)

    71→    expect(screen.getByAltText('Company A logo')).toBeInTheDocument()
    72→    expect(screen.getByAltText('Company B logo')).toBeInTheDocument()
    73→  })
    74→
    75→  it('hides trust logos when showTrustLogos is false', () => {
    76→    const logos = [
    77→      { name: 'Company A', imageUrl: '/test-a.png', alt: 'Company A logo' },
    78→      { name: 'Company B', imageUrl: '/test-b.png', alt: 'Company B logo' },
    79→    ]
    80→
    81→    renderWithTheme(<Hero trustLogos={logos} showTrustLogos={false} />)

    83→    expect(screen.queryByText('Trusted by Industry Leaders')).not.toBeInTheDocument()
    84→    expect(screen.queryByAltText('Company A logo')).not.toBeInTheDocument()
    85→    expect(screen.queryByAltText('Company B logo')).not.toBeInTheDocument()

    87→

1→import { Routes, Route, Navigate, Outlet } from 'react-router-dom'
     2→import Layout from './components/layout/Layout'
     3→import LandingPage from './pages/LandingPage'
     4→import LoginPage from './pages/LoginPage'
     5→import DashboardPage from './pages/DashboardPage'
     6→import ProjectsPage from './pages/ProjectsPage'
     7→import ProjectDetailPage from './pages/ProjectDetailPage'
     8→import EquipmentPage from './pages/EquipmentPage'
     9→import MaterialsPage from './pages/MaterialsPage'
    10→import MeetingsPage from './pages/MeetingsPage'
    11→import ApprovalsPage from './pages/ApprovalsPage'
    12→import AreasPage from './pages/AreasPage'
    13→import ContactsPage from './pages/ContactsPage'
    14→import AuditLogPage from './pages/AuditLogPage'
    15→import InspectionsPage from './pages/InspectionsPage'
    16→import RFIPage from './pages/RFIPage'
    17→
    18→function ProtectedRoute() {
    19→  const token = localStorage.getItem('authToken')
    20→  if (!token) {
    21→    return <Navigate to="/login" replace />
    22→  }
    23→  return <Outlet />
    24→}
    25→
    26→export default function App() {
    27→  return (
    28→    <Routes>
    29→        <Route path="/" element={<LandingPage />} />
    30→        <Route path="/login" element={<LoginPage />} />
    31→
    32→        <Route element={<ProtectedRoute />}>
    33→          <Route element={<Layout />}>
    34→            <Route path="/dashboard" element={<DashboardPage />} />
    35→            <Route path="/projects" element={<ProjectsPage />} />
    36→
    37→            <Route path="/projects/:projectId" element={<ProjectDetailPage />}>
    38→              <Route path="equipment" element={<EquipmentPage />} />
    39→              <Route path="materials" element={<MaterialsPage />} />
    40→              <Route path="meetings" element={<MeetingsPage />} />
    41→              <Route path="approvals" element={<ApprovalsPage />} />
    42→              <Route path="areas" element={<AreasPage />} />
    43→              <Route path="contacts" element={<ContactsPage />} />
    44→              <Route path="inspections" element={<InspectionsPage />} />
    45→              <Route path="rfis" element={<RFIPage />} />
    46→            </Route>
    47→
    48→            <Route path="/approvals" element={<ApprovalsPage />} />
    49→            <Route path="/audit" element={<AuditLogPage />} />
    50→          </Route>
    51→        </Route>
    52→
    53→        <Route path="*" element={<Navigate to="/" replace />} />
    54→      </Routes>
    55→  )
    56→}
    57→

    23→}))
    24→
    25→export function Button({
    26→  variant = 'primary',
    27→  loading = false,
    28→  icon,
    29→  iconPosition = 'start',
    30→  children,
    31→  disabled,
    32→  ...props
    33→}: ButtonProps) {
    34→  const getMuiVariant = (): MuiButtonProps['variant'] => {
    35→    switch (variant) {
    36→      case 'primary':
    37→      case 'danger':
    38→      case 'success':
    39→        return 'contained'
    40→      case 'secondary':
    41→        return 'outlined'
    42→      case 'tertiary':
    43→        return 'text'
    44→      default:
    45→        return 'contained'
    46→    }
    47→  }
    48→
    49→  const getColor = (): MuiButtonProps['color'] => {
    50→    switch (variant) {
    51→      case 'primary':
    52→        return 'primary'
    53→      case 'secondary':
    54→        return 'primary'
    55→      case 'tertiary':
    56→        return 'primary'
    57→      case 'danger':
    58→        return 'error'
    59→      case 'success':
    60→        return 'success'
    61→      default:
    62→        return 'primary'
    63→    }
    64→  }
    65→
    66→  const startIcon = icon && iconPosition === 'start' ? icon : undefined
    67→  const endIcon = icon && iconPosition === 'end' ? icon : undefined
    68→
    69→  return (
    70→    <StyledButton
    71→      variant={getMuiVariant()}
    72→      color={getColor()}
    73→      disabled={disabled || loading}
    74→      startIcon={loading ? <CircularProgress size={18} color="inherit" /> : startIcon}
    75→      endIcon={endIcon}
    76→      {...props}
    77→    >
    78→      {children}
    79→    </StyledButton>
    80→  )
